descriptions.content:
The experiential auxiliary མྱོང་ signifies that the subject has already, at least once, experienced the action to which མྱོང་ refers. The verb preceding the auxiliary མྱོང་ must be in the present tense. When མྱོང་ isn’t followed by anything, the implication is egophoric. In this case, it is used with the first person, which may be either the subject or the direct or indirect object. In other cases, མྱོང་ again becomes a full verb and must be followed by an assertive past auxiliary: ཡོད་རེད།, པ་རེད།. In English it may be translated by “has/have ever....”

  • ང་འབྲུག་ཡུལ་ལ་འགྲོ་མྱོང་། “I’ve been to Bhutan.” (Literally: “I’ve gone....”)
  • ཁོས་ང་བརྡུངས་མྱོང་། “He has (previously) hit me.”
  • ཁོང་ངའི་རྩ་ལ་ཕེབས་མྱོང་། “He’s been to my place.” (Literally: “He’s come....”)
  • ཁོང་འབྲུག་ཡུལ་ལ་ཕེབས་མྱོང་ཡོད་རེད། He has been to Bhutan.” (Literally: “He has gone....”)
